William Shatner is a Canadian-American actor, author, and director, widely recognized for his iconic role as Captain James T. Kirk in the popular science fiction franchise Star Trek. Born on October 22, 1931, in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, Shatner began his acting career at a young age, studying at the prestigious National Theatre School of Canada.

In 1964, Shatner made his big breakthrough with the role of Captain Kirk in the original Star Trek series, which ran from 1966 to 1969. The show's innovative concepts, groundbreaking special effects, and thought-provoking storylines earned it a dedicated fanbase and turned Shatner into a cultural icon. The series was a precursor to the iconic Star Trek films, in which Shatner reprised his role as Kirk.

Shatner has also made a significant impact on television with other notable performances, including his portrayal of the charismatic lawyer Denny Crane in the legal drama The Practice and its spin-off, Boston Legal. These roles earned Shatner two Primetime Emmy Awards for Outstanding Lead Actor in a Drama Series.

In addition to his acting career, Shatner has ventured into directing and hosting, producing several successful television shows, such as Shelley Duvall's Tall Tales & Legends and the reality competition series, The $100,000 Pyramid.

Shatner's interest in acting extends beyond the screen. In 2011, he published his autobiography, Up Till Now: My Life as an Actor, and later wrote several novels, including The Return and Beyond the Limits. Throughout his career, Shatner has been celebrated for his longevity, versatility, and unwavering dedication to his craft, cementing his status as a beloved and enduring figure in popular culture.

Apart from acting, Shatner has written numerous books, including a Star Trek autobiography, a collection of short stories, and memoirs. He has also written several children's books and has released several albums as a singer, with the most notable being his cover of the Beatles' song "Lucy in the Sky with Diamonds" in 1999.

He was discovered by director Michael Gordon, who cast him in his play "A Patriot for Me," for which he received a Tony Award nomination.

Shatner's breakthrough came with his portrayal of Captain Kirk on Star Trek, which premiered in 1966. The show became a cultural phenomenon, spanning seven successful seasons, and has since become a pop culture icon. In addition to his acting, Shatner is also a musician, releasing a number of albums and singles under the moniker "Leonard Nimoy, William Shatner, and Sy Snooze."

Throughout his career, Shatner has made numerous guest appearances on television shows, appeared in films like "Tattoo," "The Empire Strikes Back," and "Star Trek III: The Search for Spock," and even played the role of a fictionalized version of himself in the 2004 film "Shatner's World: We Just Live in Dangerous Times." Shatner has also been active in politics, hosting a radio talk show for The Howard Stern Show and serving as the Grand Marshal of the Rose Parade.

Aside from his acting and music, Shatner has authored several books, including novels like "Seven Days," and non-fiction works like "Star Trek: The Next Generation: The Official Companion." In 2011, he appeared in the reality show "Battle for Seaworld," which documented his efforts to save an injured beluga whale.

Today, at the age of 90, William Shatner remains an influential and active figure in entertainment and popular culture. His career spans over six decades, and his contributions to film, television, and music have earned him a place among the greats in the world of performing arts.
